text: uh
dump any dumb tano here the internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review of this new usta lost
project before the glinting spell
unvests this is the sophomore album of a
black metal project spearheaded by
multi-instrumentalist
songwriter singer will skarstad will has
been active in the east coast metal
scene for over a decade now i recommend
very highly one of his other bands the
black metal outfit yellow eyes this
project like i said dabbles in the same
genre but damn if this thing isn't
aesthetically just on another level
before the glinting spell on vests
wouldn't be the first black metal lp
with a lo-fi slant but will and his
brother who i believe is on production
here embrace
this sound as a means of sometimes
evoking some pretty nostalgic feels the
way the guitars and bass consistently
meld together in these tracks gives
almost a fuzzy warmth the dusty analog
synthesizers on this thing are a nice
touch as well for sure it's black metal
but there's something about it that
feels as if it should be the soundtrack
to
some kind of 80s b-movie slasher flick
which i can't name a whole lot of
records in this style that work that
angle much less do it well what's also
impressive is what will does with all
these layers of guitars bass and
synthesizers because across this lp he
comes through with some really righteous
compositions multi-faceted too on the
bandcamp page for this record i believe
this thing is described as
an experiment in indulgence and yeah i
kind of agree you wouldn't think tracks
that are six to eight minutes long would
just be bursting at the seams with ideas
but yeah they are which is sometimes to
the detriment of the memorability of
these tracks as there are so many ideas
flying by you within so many minutes but
it still doesn't change the fact many of
these tracks have me on the edge of my
seat waiting for the next idea or a
passage to unfold the first track alone
feels like several different songs or
pieces flowing into each other from the
stunning synth intro and the throttling
blast beats in the first leg to the
driving grooves and moonlit melody
changes that are offered in the second
third the intro to the song stinging
stone is so heavy and so thick it almost
feels like a shoegaze cut the ghostly
druid chants that
introduced themselves suddenly in the
midst of the track are great as well i
wish they came back around in the song
too but i guess more twisted maze-like
passages of guitar and bass are fine as
well but this section of the record is
actually one of the few that stagnates
for me a little bit not a whole lot in
terms of like progression or evolution
on these riffs or rhythms eventually the
whole thing breaks into an abrupt finish
with these slowly fading synthesizers
the slower pacing in 3 4 groove on white
marble column air does seem to leave
more room for detail and nuance it's a
pretty enchanting track too with its
opening bells and
swirling passages of synthesizers and
guitar the whole track feels like i'm
going back to the dark ages for either
some kind of castle siege on a stormy
night or
some pagan ritual love the way the drums
suddenly pick up the pace into even more
mesmerizing sections of guitar and synth
dense compositions dense instrumentation
there's just so many layers of it to eat
up very much to a fault on the title
track though where we'll throw so many
compositional ideas and passages into
this song they come off a little
disjointed the guitar and vocal work
isn't exactly bringing anything to fresh
or new aesthetically it feels like the
record is painting itself into a corner
a little bit from here the record saves
the biggest cuts for last there's the
eight-minute spider-tongue memory ester
which suffers from a lot of the same
fragmentation of the title track not to
mention some of the rhythms and grooves
presented on this track are laggy and
stiff but in fairness the longer run
time of this song does allow will to
let some of these ideas and changes
breathe like the epic and almost
medieval chord progressions being built
on in the final leg then we have the
nine minute finisher bright window
closing despite this thing being so long
it's actually one of the most fluid and
cohesive cuts on the entire record every
groove change feels so tight with the
next uh every lick feels so close either
in rhythm or key the melodies and
harmonies on this one are some of the
most like devilish and sinister and just
instantaneously just memorable and sharp
on the entire record too plus the way
some of these spacious synthesizers
color the leftover space it's kind of
like a john carpenter piece and what is
that haunting group chant at the very
end of the track i can't quite put my
finger on it it sounds vaguely foreign
and maybe sampled but i haven't really
heard a chant in this style in context
with a black metal record but it just
fits perfectly overall this thing is a
very grim but colorful record that
brings a lot of
dark but cool ear candy tortured vocal
performances transcendental guitar
harmonies a great spectral synthesizers
creative lo-fi production it's a good lp
and i think one of the more
under-appreciated metal gems i have
heard in a minute i'm surprised more
people aren't talking about it but uh
feeling a decent two strong seven on
this one tran position have you given
this album a listen did you love it did
you hate it what would you rate it
you're the best you're the best what
should i review next hit the like if you
like please subscribe and please don't
cry hit the bell as well over here next
to my head it's another video you can
check out hit that up or the link to
subscribe to the channel anthony fantano
black metal
forever
